Richard Bonneau joined the Simons Foundation in 2014 to develop next-generation computational biology methods for the Simons Center for Data Analysis. He focuses on creating new methods for using protein structure modeling to interpret genetic variation and new methods for understanding biological networks. Before coming to the foundation, Bonneau was a senior scientist at the Institute for Systems Biology in Seattle, Washington, and before that he was a senior scientist at Structural GenomiX in San Diego, California. Currently, he is associate professor of biology and computer science as well as co-director of the Social Media and Political Participation Lab at New York University. He holds a B.A. in biochemistry from Florida State University and a Ph.D. in biomolecular structure and design from the University of Washington.

My research focusses mainly in the area of computational linguistics: annotation, lexicon creation, machine translation,  information extraction, terminology extraction, and other areas. I worked for Ezra Black of the Fred Jellinek's speech group in 1989-1990. He hired me to produce a dictionary of nouns and he wanted me to enter 1000 words per day, which I initially thought was impossible, but was actually able to do by the end of my stay. I worked for David Johnson from 1991-1992 on a Relational Grammar based parsing system which resulted in a paper (http://www.aclweb.org/anthology/P/P93/P93-1014.pdf). My work there introduced me to several different graph-based (and feature structure based) linguistic theories. This influenced not only by PhD thesis, but some of my recent work constructing the GLARF semantic parser.
